awd_titl_txt: TC: Medium: Collaborative Research: Towards Formal, Risk-Aware Authorization
awd_abstract_narration: Traditional security authorization decisions are black and white: a user either satisfies a particular access policy or does not.  This rigidity is a handicap in our complex and unpredictable world.  As a result, even security-conscious organizations typically grossly overprovision principals with access rights and/or underconstrain access policies to ensure that principals can always carry out the organization's mission effectively and respond to unexpected opportunities and challenges.  This project focuses on developing dynamic and risk-aware approaches to access control that allow organizations to make security-critical decisions in the face of incomplete information and unexpected circumstances.  This is accomplished by combining proof-theoretic access controls with economic models of risk.  In the event that the expected proof of authorization for an action cannot be generated, the systems developed in this project carry out an efficient search for similar proofs of authorization that minimize the overall risk incurred by deviating from the expected.  This approach allows policies to adapt dynamically to the changing context of the systems in which they are deployed. This research will have several benefits, including increased system availability during disasters or other uncommon cases not explicitly modeled by policies; reduced instances of permission creep, as overprovisioning users is no longer required to ensure that an organization's business needs are met; a quantifiable means of assessing how policies are actually used and how they might be changed to better reflect the evolution of organizations; and the development of metrics for assessing access control risks.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional authorization decisions are black and white: a user either does or does not satisfy a particular access policy.  This rigidity is a handicap in our complex, dynamic, and unpredictable world.  As a result, even security-conscious tech-savvy organizations typically grossly overprovision principals with access rights and/or underconstrain access policies to ensure that principals can always carry out the organization's mission effectively and respond to unexpected opportunities and challenges. This project focused on understanding how notions of risk and risk tolerance play into access control and data sharing systems, and on developing approaches to monitor and accomodate risk.  In conducting this research, advances have been made in several key technical areas:

  • Quantitative Analysis of Proofs of Authorization: We have shown that it is possible to use the evidence required to make access control decisions to examine these binary outcomes within a more continuous space. To better understand this process, we have developed a formal model that allows us to quantitatively reason about the outcomes of the policy enforcement process in both absolute (i.e., user to ideal case) and relative (i.e., user to user) terms.  To this end, we have explored several interesting classes of proof scoring functions for assessing the robustness of authorization decisions, and developed criteria under which these types of functions can be composed with one another. We further show that these types of functions can be extended to quantify how close unauthorized users are to satisfying policies, which can be a useful risk metric for decision making under unexpected circumstances.
  • Insured Access: Although risk-mitigation is a relatively new   subfield of computer security, the insurance agency has been   attempting to understand and quantify risk for quite some time. During this project, we have adapted techniques from the   actuarial community to model and understand the risks of information flows within large virtual organizations. These   techniques can be used to incentivize useful flows of information   between members of a virtual organization, while also minimizing   improper use of data.
  • Quantifying the Costs of Access Control: Historically, access   control systems have been compared to one another by assessing their relative expressive power.  While useful for making binary comparisons between access control approaches, this offers relatively little insight into how well these schemes perform   within the context of a given application.  We have begun to   develop an approach for making more quantitative comparisons   between schemes, assessing costs like administrative overheads, policy error rates, and system stuttering that can lead to increases in disclosure risk.
  • Systems Support for Controlling Disclosure Risk: We developed   system tools to help limit over-sharing of information in   distributed systems relative to two classes of applications. Specifically, we developed a privacy-aware distributed relational database query optimizer that enables users to specify hard and soft privacy constraints to be upheld while determines how portions of a query should be parceled out amongst servers in a distributed system. We have also developed a user-friendly system for that leverages social authentication and untrusted cloud storage provides to create a flexible and secure means of sharing user location amongst social peers.  These two disparate systems show that taking a user-centric approach to data management can help limit disclosure risks in real-world systems.
